elements.content: Four new metal coordination polymers, [Cd(pybma)2] n (1), [Zn(pybma)(C2O4)0.5·0.5H2O] n (2), [Co(pybma)(C2O4)0.5] n (3), and [Zn3(pybma)2(HBTC)2(H2O)4] n (4) [pybma = 2-(2-pyridinyl-benzimidazolyl) acetic anion; H3BTC =1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate], have been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions and structurally characterized by element analyses, IR spectroscopy, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses. 1 has a one-dimensional (1D) chain structure, which contains two kinds of rings. Interestingly, 2 has a two-dimensional (2D) metal−organic framework and can be seen as the unity of two parallel double-stranded helices, in which the helices are bridged by oxalate ligands. 3 has a 2D framework built from 1D chains and ox bridges. 4 has 2D layer framework which is assembled into a three-dimensional (3D) framework with two kinds of channels. Polymers 1, 2, and 4 exhibit obvious fluorescent emissions in the solid state at room temperature; no fluorescent emission is observed in polymer 3.

Interestingly, 2 has a two-dimensional (2D) metal-organic framework and can be seen as the unity of two parallel double-stranded helices, in which the helices are bridged by oxalate ligands. 3 has a 2D framework built from 1D chains and ox bridges. 4 has 2D layer framework which is assembled into a three-dimensional (3D) framework with two kinds of channels. Polymers 1, 2, and 4 exhibit obvious fluorescent emissions in the solid state at room temperature; no fluorescent emission is observed in polymer 3.

elements.content: Four new coordination polymers have been synthesized by the reaction of 2-(2-pyridinyl-benzimidazolyl) acetate and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate under hydrothermal conditions and structurally characterized by element analyses, IR spectroscopy, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Their fluorescent properties have been investigated in the solid state.

Their fluorescent properties have been investigated in the solid state.

elements.content: The rational design and synthesis of coordination polymers is currently of great interest in the field of supramolecular chemistry and crystal engineering, not only because of their intriguing structural motifs but also because of their potential applications in catalysis, molecular adsorption, magnetism, nonlinear optics, molecular sensing, and heterogeneous catalysis. It has been documented that the geometries of organic ligands have a great effect on the structural frameworks of such coordination polymers; thus, much effort has been devoted to modify the building blocks and to control the assembled motifs for required products via selecting different organic ligands. The multifunctional ligands containing N- and O-donors (Scheme a−e) have attracted great attention because they may induce diversity in the coordination mode and interesting properties. In this study, we chose 2-(2-pyridinyl-benzimidazolyl) acetic anion (pybma, Scheme f) as a bridging ligand to construct four complexes based on two characteristics as follows: (1) It has larger conjugated π-systems than pyridine and 2,2′-bipy; therefore, π−π stacking interactions may play important roles in the formation of their complexes in the solid state; (2) compared with the rigid 2-(2-pyridyl)-benzimidazole, pybma has an added functional group of -CH2−COO−, whose flexibility and geometric requirements may result in chiral networks. And using achiral ligands to generate chiral networks with helices accord with the current trend in crystal engineering research.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The rational design and synthesis of coordination polymers is currently of great interest in the field of supramolecular chemistry and crystal engineering, not only because of their intriguing structural motifs but also because of their potential applications in catalysis, molecular adsorption, magnetism, nonlinear optics, molecular sensing, and heterogeneous catalysis. It has been documented that the geometries of organic ligands have a great effect on the structural frameworks of such coordination polymers; thus, much effort has been devoted to modify the building blocks and to control the assembled motifs for required products via selecting different organic ligands. The multifunctional ligands containing N- and O-donors (Scheme a-e) have attracted great attention because they may induce diversity in the coordination mode and interesting properties. In this study, we chose 2-(2-pyridinyl-benzimidazolyl) acetic anion (pybma, Scheme f) as a bridging ligand to construct four complexes based on two characteristics as follows: (1) It has larger conjugated π-systems than pyridine and 2,2'-bipy; therefore, π-π stacking interactions may play important roles in the formation of their complexes in the solid state; (2) compared with the rigid 2-(2-pyridyl)-benzimidazole, pybma has an added functional group of -CH2-COO-, whose flexibility and geometric requirements may result in chiral networks. And using achiral ligands to generate chiral networks with helices accord with the current trend in crystal engineering research.

elements.clean_text: 1  Several Multifunctional Ligands Containing N- and O-Donors

elements.content: Moreover, owning to the diversity of the coordination modes and high structural stability, the multidentate O-donor organic polycarboxylate ligands, such as oxalate acid and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate (H3BTC), have been extensively employed to construct high-dimensional structures. Considering all the aspects above, we present here the syntheses, structures, and fluorescent properties of four new coordination polymers: [Cd(pybma)2] n (1), [Zn(pybma)(C2O4)0.5·0.5H2O] n (2), [Co(pybma)(C2O4)0.5] n (3), [Zn3(pybma)2(HBTC)2(H2O)4] n (4).

Considering all the aspects above, we present here the syntheses, structures, and fluorescent properties of four new coordination polymers: [Cd(pybma)2] n  (1), [Zn(pybma)(C2O4)0.5⋅0.5H2O] n  (2), [Co(pybma)(C2O4)0.5] n  (3), [Zn3(pybma)2(HBTC)2(H2O)4] n  (4).

Element analyses (C, H, N) were carried out on a Perkin-Elmer model 240C analyzer. The IR spectra were obtained as KBr pellets on a VECTOR 22 spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analyses were performed on a TGA V5.1A Dupont 2100 instrument from room temperature to 750 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min in air. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) measurements were performed on a Philips X′pert MPD Pro X-ray diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (0.15418 nm), in which the X-ray tube was operated at 40 kV and 40 mA.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Measurements

The ligand pybma was synthesized as reported previously. All other starting materials are commercially available and used without further purification. Element analyses (C, H, N) were carried out on a Perkin-Elmer model 240C analyzer. The IR spectra were obtained as KBr pellets on a VECTOR 22 spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analyses were performed on a TGA V5.1A Dupont 2100 instrument from room temperature to 750 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min in air. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) measurements were performed on a Philips X'pert MPD Pro X-ray diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (0.15418 nm), in which the X-ray tube was operated at 40 kV and 40 mA.

elements.content: The crystal structures were determined by single-crystal X-ray analyses. Data collections were performed using a Bruker-APS SMART CCD area detector diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation with an φω mode (λ = 0.71073 Å). The structures were solved with direct methods using the SHELXTL program and refined anisotropically with SHELXTL using full-matrix least squares procedures. The structural plots were drawn using SHELXTL and Diamond. Crystal data and experimental details for the complexes are given in Table . Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table .
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Determination

The crystal structures were determined by single-crystal X-ray analyses. Data collections were performed using a Bruker-APS SMART CCD area detector diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation with an φω mode (λ = 0.71073 Å). The structures were solved with direct methods using the SHELXTL program and refined anisotropically with SHELXTL using full-matrix least squares procedures. The structural plots were drawn using SHELXTL and Diamond. Crystal data and experimental details for the complexes are given in Table . Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table .

elements.content: Polymer 1 is a new one-dimensional (1D) structure containing two different ring units. Each CdII center is six-coordinated by four nitrogen atoms from two different pybma ligands in bichelating fashion, two oxygen atoms from different carboxylate groups of pybma in monochelating fashion, showing a distorted octahedral coordination geometry (Figure a). Two pybma ligands bridge two CdII centers with head-to-end conformation to form a 14-membered M2L2 ring (A) structure with the Cd···Cd distance of 7.3853(15) Å (Figure b), and another two pybma ligands coordinate to CdII centers of adjacent M2L2 rings (A) also in head-to-end model to form a 28-membered M4L4 macrocycle (B) structure with the Cd···Cd distance of 8.8030(15) Å and 13.1801(23) Å, respectively. A 1D ladderlike chain is formed by A and B rings arranged along b axis side by side (Figure b).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Description of the Crystal Structure of [Cd(pybma)2] n  (1)

Polymer 1 is a new one-dimensional (1D) structure containing two different ring units. Each CdII center is six-coordinated by four nitrogen atoms from two different pybma ligands in bichelating fashion, two oxygen atoms from different carboxylate groups of pybma in monochelating fashion, showing a distorted octahedral coordination geometry (Figure a). Two pybma ligands bridge two CdII centers with head-to-end conformation to form a 14-membered M2L2 ring (A) structure with the Cd⋅⋅⋅Cd distance of 7.3853(15) Å (Figure b), and another two pybma ligands coordinate to CdII centers of adjacent M2L2 rings (A) also in head-to-end model to form a 28-membered M4L4 macrocycle (B) structure with the Cd⋅⋅⋅Cd distance of 8.8030(15) Å and 13.1801(23) Å, respectively. A 1D ladderlike chain is formed by A and B rings arranged along b axis side by side (Figure b).

elements.content: X-ray crystallography reveals that a lamellar framework structure of polymer 2 is built from interlinking of two different helices. The asymmetric unit contains a ZnII center and one pybma ligand, half of one bis-bidentate oxalate anion and a half-solvated water molecules. The ZnII center is coordinated to two oxygen atoms from oxalate anion, two nitrogen atoms and two carboxylate oxygen atoms from different pybma ligands. The geometry around the Zn cation is a distorted octahedron, with Zn−O and Zn−N distances in the range of 2.037(4)−2.369(4) Å and 2.069(5)−2.125(5) Å (Figure a). Interestingly, the asymmetry of the pybma was “locked” by the coordination of the N and O with zinc cation and might be transferred throughout the crystal structure to “direct” the formation of a chiral network. As described in Figure b, the pybma ligands bridge each pair of adjacent ZnII to form a 1D left-handed (M) helical infinite chain around the crystallographic 21 axis in the b direction with a long pitch of 9.81Å. The remaining coordination cites of ZnII within the chain were taken by oxalate anions like parallels. So the neighboring chains have to be a right-handed (P) helix for the request of the coordination of oxalate anion in the primal formed left-handed chain to the ZnII in neighboring helix. That means the left-handed chirality of the original formed chain is transferred oppositely to the adjacent helix by the coordination of oxalate anions bridges. Because left-handed and right-handed helical chains coexist in the crystal structure, the whole crystal is racemic and does not exhibit chirality. As discussed above, the occurrence of helical structure may be attributable to the flexibility of the pybma group.
elements.clean_text:
Description of the Crystal Structure of [Zn(pybma)(C2O4)0.5⋅0.5H2O] n  (2)

X-ray crystallography reveals that a lamellar framework structure of polymer 2 is built from interlinking of two different helices. The asymmetric unit contains a ZnII center and one pybma ligand, half of one bis-bidentate oxalate anion and a half-solvated water molecules. The ZnII center is coordinated to two oxygen atoms from oxalate anion, two nitrogen atoms and two carboxylate oxygen atoms from different pybma ligands. The geometry around the Zn cation is a distorted octahedron, with Zn-O and Zn-N distances in the range of 2.037(4)-2.369(4) Å and 2.069(5)-2.125(5) Å (Figure a). Interestingly, the asymmetry of the pybma was "locked" by the coordination of the N and O with zinc cation and might be transferred throughout the crystal structure to "direct" the formation of a chiral network. As described in Figure b, the pybma ligands bridge each pair of adjacent ZnII to form a 1D left-handed (M) helical infinite chain around the crystallographic 21 axis in the b direction with a long pitch of 9.81Å. The remaining coordination cites of ZnII within the chain were taken by oxalate anions like parallels. So the neighboring chains have to be a right-handed (P) helix for the request of the coordination of oxalate anion in the primal formed left-handed chain to the ZnII in neighboring helix. That means the left-handed chirality of the original formed chain is transferred oppositely to the adjacent helix by the coordination of oxalate anions bridges. Because left-handed and right-handed helical chains coexist in the crystal structure, the whole crystal is racemic and does not exhibit chirality. As discussed above, the occurrence of helical structure may be attributable to the flexibility of the pybma group.

elements.content: The structure of polymer 3 is a two-dimensional (2D) framework in which the asymmetric unit contains one cobalt(II) atom, one pybma ligand, and half of an oxalate ligand. The cobalt atom is octahedrally coordinated by two oxygen atoms from one oxalate anion, two nitrogen atoms from one pybma ligand, and the other two oxygen atoms from two different pybma ligands (Figure a). As shown in Figure b, the pybma ligand acts as a μ3-bridge through one μ2-bridging carboxylate and two chelating nitrogen atoms to link three cobalt (II) atoms. The second building unit (SBU) is a dicobalt carboxylate moiety, where two Co atoms are bridged by two μ2-bridging carboxylate groups of two different pybma ligands, with a Co···Co distance of 5.0328(11) Å. The SBUs are linked by two pybma ligands ex carboxylate moiety to result in a 1D ladder of [Co2(pybma)2] n with the two adjacent dicobalt cores distance of 9.0110(21)Å along the a axis. The 2D network structure of 3 is achieved by the ox groups coordinating to Co atoms in two adjacent 1D chains, whereas the Co−Co distance with the oxalate bridge is 5.4539(13) Å (Figure b). In addition, strong π−π stacking interactions are observed in the 1D ladder of [Co2(pybma)2] n with the plane-to-plane distance of adjacent 2-(2-pyridyl)-benzimidazole being 3.6619(93) Å which induce the formation of M2L2 rings in the 1D ladder (Figure b). A better insight into the nature of 3 can be achieved by the application of topological approach with reducing multidimensional structures to simple node-and-linker nets. The simplified structure of 3 with bridging mode between the metal ions and the ox anions is a hybrid chain structure, which can be regarded as a grid 2D sheet with (4, 4) net topology.

elements.content: X-ray crystallography reveals that the structure of 4 is a 2D metal−organic coordination network and crystallizes in the P1̅ space group. The asymmetric unit contains two kinds of ZnII atoms (Zn1 and Zn2) and one pybma ligand, one HBTC anion and two coordinated water molecules. The Zn1 atom is coordinated by two bridging carboxylate O atoms from two different pybma ligands, two bridging carboxylate O atoms from two different HBTC ligands and two water O atoms. With Zn−O distances in the range of 2.067(4)−2.195(4) Å and O−Zn−O angles in the range of 88.58(14)°−180°, the coordination polyhedron of Zn1 atom can be viewed as a slightly distorted octahedron. The Zn2 is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from the pybma ligand, two oxygen atoms from HBTC anion, and two oxygen atoms from one coordinated water and one pybma ligand, respectively (Figure a). The six coordinated polyhedron also can be described as a slightly distorted octahedral geometry with coordination angles in the range of 76.00(18)°−170.47(16)°. As shown in Figure b, the pybma ligand acts as a μ3-bridge through one μ2-bridging carboxylate and two chelating nitrogen atoms to link three zinc(II) atoms to form an infinite ladder of [Zn3(pybma)2] n . Compared with polymer 3, very weak stacking interactions are also observed in the 1D ladder of [Zn3(pybma)2] n that the plane-to-plane distance of adjacent 2-(2-pyridyl)-benzimidazole is 3.998(7) Å. The adjacent chains are interconnected by the HBTC anions to form a 2D layer parallel to bc plane, and the plane-to-plane distance of adjacent HBTC are 3.293(47) and 8.660(64) Å, respectively. Moreover, the 2D network can be regarded as being built up from two kinds of interlocking rings. The HBTC ligands bridge Zn1 and Zn2 with two carboxylates to form a 24-membered ring (A ring) structure and a 30-membered ring (B ring). Extensive hydrogen-bonding interactions also exist in the adjacent 2D layers of polymer 4. The geometrical parameters pertaining to the hydrogen bonds are collected in Table . The 2D layers are assembled into a three-dimensional (3D) framework with two kinds of channels (channel A and channel B) via hydrogen bonds and weak π−π stacking interactions (Figure c).

The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of polymers 1−4 was performed in a N2 atmosphere at a heating rate of 20 °C·min−1. Polymers 1 and 3 show similar thermal behaviors, which are different from those of 2 and 4 (Figure ). The TGA curves for 1 show that it begins to decompose up to 370 °C. The TGA diagram of 2 exhibits an initial weight loss of 2.3% from 50 to 180 °C corresponding to the loss of half of a lattice water molecule (calcd 2.4%), and the decomposition of 2 begins above 450 °C. The TGA curves of 3 indicate that the frameworks for 3 are stable up to 440 °C and then begin to decompose upon further heating. 3 underwent a rapid and significant weight loss of 69.4% in the temperature range of 440−560 °C which corresponds to the loss of the pybma ligands (calcd.71.0%). The relatively high thermal stability may be due to the strong π−π stacking interactions in the framework structures. The TGA curves for 4 display a gradual weight loss of 5.1% from 170 to 260 °C, which may be attributed to the loss of four coordinated water molecules per formula (calcd 6.1%). The frameworks of 4 lost their stability around 330 °C. The purities of polymers are confirmed by X-ray power diffraction analyses, in which the experimental spectra of polymers 1−4 are almost consistent with their simulated spectra ().

elements.content: The emission spectra of complexes 1−4 in the solid state at room temperature are investigated, as depicted in Figure . It can be observed that solid state 1, 2, and 4 exhibit obvious fluorescence which can be compared with similar Zn, Cd coordination complexes. 3 is not observed to have a fluorescence at room temperature, which attribute to the paramagnetic nature of Co2+ ion and coordination of Co2+ with the pybma ligand. There is very strong emission of pybma with a wavelength from 360 to 430 nm (λmax = 399 nm) upon excitation at 350 nm, but no fluorescence is observed in H3BTC. When the ligand is coordinated to zinc and cadmium centers, blue luminescence is observed. In contrast to pybma, polymer 1 in the solid state has a slightly broader emission band with a λmax value of 410 nm and is red-shifted by 10 nm. Polymer 2 in the solid state has a very wide emission band (bandwidth at half-height 80−90 nm) with λmax at 419 nm. The emission spectra of 4 shows a broad emission band (bandwidth at half-height 65 nm) centered at 420 nm. And the fluorescence of 4 is stronger than 1 and 2. It is clear that a significant red shift of the emission occurs in 1, 2, and 4, compared with pybma, which is probably attributed to ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT), which has been found in many reported MOFs.

Luminescent Properties

The emission spectra of complexes 1-4 in the solid state at room temperature are investigated, as depicted in Figure . It can be observed that solid state 1, 2, and 4 exhibit obvious fluorescence which can be compared with similar Zn, Cd coordination complexes. 3 is not observed to have a fluorescence at room temperature, which attribute to the paramagnetic nature of Co2+ ion and coordination of Co2+ with the pybma ligand. There is very strong emission of pybma with a wavelength from 360 to 430 nm (λmax = 399 nm) upon excitation at 350 nm, but no fluorescence is observed in H3BTC. When the ligand is coordinated to zinc and cadmium centers, blue luminescence is observed. In contrast to pybma, polymer 1 in the solid state has a slightly broader emission band with a λmax value of 410 nm and is red-shifted by 10 nm. Polymer 2 in the solid state has a very wide emission band (bandwidth at half-height 80-90 nm) with λmax at 419 nm. The emission spectra of 4 shows a broad emission band (bandwidth at half-height 65 nm) centered at 420 nm. And the fluorescence of 4 is stronger than 1 and 2. It is clear that a significant red shift of the emission occurs in 1, 2, and 4, compared with pybma, which is probably attributed to ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT), which has been found in many reported MOFs.

elements.content: Four new coordination polymers based on pybma have been successfully prepared and structurally characterized. And the luminescence of polymers at room temperature is also investigated. From the above results, it was found that due to the flexibility and rigidity of the bifunctional bypma ligand, the polymers with interesting structures could be obtained. This work will undoubtedly deepen our systemic understanding of the structural functionality and the confor-mational flexibility of the 2-(2-pyridinyl-benzimidazolyl) acetic anion (pybma). Further work is in progress to prepare novel topologically structural complexes based on pybma ligand with interesting chemical and physical properties.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Four new coordination polymers based on pybma have been successfully prepared and structurally characterized. And the luminescence of polymers at room temperature is also investigated. From the above results, it was found that due to the flexibility and rigidity of the bifunctional bypma ligand, the polymers with interesting structures could be obtained. This work will undoubtedly deepen our systemic understanding of the structural functionality and the confor-mational flexibility of the 2-(2-pyridinyl-benzimidazolyl) acetic anion (pybma). Further work is in progress to prepare novel topologically structural complexes based on pybma ligand with interesting chemical and physical properties.

Polymers 1 and 3 show similar thermal behaviors, which are different from those of 2 and 4 (Figure ). The TGA curves for 1 show that it begins to decompose up to 370 °C. The TGA diagram of 2 exhibits an initial weight loss of 2.3% from 50 to 180 °C corresponding to the loss of half of a lattice water molecule (calcd 2.4%), and the decomposition of 2 begins above 450 °C. The TGA curves of 3 indicate that the frameworks for 3 are stable up to 440 °C and then begin to decompose upon further heating. 3 underwent a rapid and significant weight loss of 69.4% in the temperature range of 440−560 °C which corresponds to the loss of the pybma ligands (calcd.71.0%). The relatively high thermal stability may be due to the strong π−π stacking interactions in the framework structures. The TGA curves for 4 display a gradual weight loss of 5.1% from 170 to 260 °C, which may be attributed to the loss of four coordinated water molecules per formula (calcd 6.1%). The frameworks of 4 lost their stability around 330 °C. The purities of polymers are confirmed by X-ray power diffraction analyses, in which the experimental spectra of polymers 1−4 are almost consistent with their simulated spectra ().

Luminescent Properties

The emission spectra of complexes 1−4 in the solid state at room temperature are investigated, as depicted in Figure . It can be observed that solid state 1, 2, and 4 exhibit obvious fluorescence which can be compared with similar Zn, Cd coordination complexes. 3 is not observed to have a fluorescence at room temperature, which attribute to the paramagnetic nature of Co2+ ion and coordination of Co2+ with the pybma ligand. There is very strong emission of pybma with a wavelength from 360 to 430 nm (λmax = 399 nm) upon excitation at 350 nm, but no fluorescence is observed in H3BTC. When the ligand is coordinated to zinc and cadmium centers, blue luminescence is observed. In contrast to pybma, polymer 1 in the solid state has a slightly broader emission band with a λmax value of 410 nm and is red-shifted by 10 nm. Polymer 2 in the solid state has a very wide emission band (bandwidth at half-height 80−90 nm) with λmax at 419 nm. The emission spectra of 4 shows a broad emission band (bandwidth at half-height 65 nm) centered at 420 nm. And the fluorescence of 4 is stronger than 1 and 2. It is clear that a significant red shift of the emission occurs in 1, 2, and 4, compared with pybma, which is probably attributed to ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT), which has been found in many reported MOFs.
